Coord50.51392414.165352inlineregion:CZ-US_type:landmarkSite of Theresienstadt entrance with Arbeit Macht Frei "Labour Makes Free" Gate"langde''Arbeit macht frei''" (IPA-deˈaɐ̯baɪt ˈmaxt ˈfʁaɪ) is a German phrase meaning "work makes (you) free."Encyclopedia of the Holocaust,Yad Vashem, 1990, vol. 4, p. 1751.The slogan was placed over the entrances to a number ofNazi concentration campsduringWorld War II, includingAuschwitz concentration campAuschwitz I, where it was made by prisoners with metalwork skills and erected by order of the Nazis in June 1940.
article.heading: Origin
article.paragraph: The expression comes from the title of a novel by GermanPhilologyphilologistLorenz Diefenbach,Arbeit macht frei: Erzhlung von Lorenz Diefenbach(1873), in which gamblers and fraudsters find the path to virtue through labour.cite newsConnollyKatehttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/dec/18/auschwitz-arbeit-macht-frei-signPoland declares state of emergency after 'Arbeit Macht Frei' stolen from AuschwitzThe Guardian18 December 2009Diefenbach, Lorenz.Arbeit macht frei: Erzhlung von Lorenz Diefenbach. J. Khtmann's Buchhandlung, 1873.The phrase was also used in French ("le travail rend libre!") byAuguste Forel, a Swiss entomologist, neuroanatomist and psychiatrist, in his "Fourmis de la Suisse" ["Ants of Switzerland"] (1920).cite webhttp://www.archive.org/stream/lesfourmisdelasu00fore#page/n7/mode/2upLes fourmis de la Suisse (2nd Ed.)AugusteForelAuguste ForelLa Chaux-de-FondsImprimarie cooperative1920French22 November 2010In 1922, the Deutsche Schulverein of Vienna, an ethnic nationalist "protective" organization of Germans within the Austrian empire, printed membership stamps with the phraseArbeit macht frei.
article.heading: Use by the Nazis
article.paragraph:
Image:Camp ArbeitMachtFrei.JPGthumb200pxSachsenhausen concentration campKZ Sachsenhausen
Coord52.76588213.264275inlineregion:DE-BB_type:landmarkSite of Sachsenhausen entrance with Arbeit Macht Frei "Work Makes Free" GateImage:Arbeit Macht Frei Dachau 8235.jpgthumb200pxrightDachau concentration campDachau
Coord48.26834711.466865inlineregion:DE-BY_type:landmarkSite of Dachau entrance with Arbeit Macht Frei "Work Makes Free" GateThe slogan "Arbeit macht frei" was placed at the entrances to a number ofNazi GermanyNaziconcentration camps. The slogan's use in this instance was ordered bySchutzstaffelSSGeneralTheodor Eicke, inspector of concentration camps and second commandant ofDachau Concentration Camp.

The slogan can still be seen at several sites, including over the entrance toAuschwitz concentration campAuschwitz Iwhere, according to BBC historianLaurence Reesin his "Auschwitz: a New History", the sign was erected by order of commandantRudolf Hss. This particular sign was made by prisoner-labourers includingJan Liwacz. The sign features an upside-down 'B', which has been interpreted as an act of defiance by the prisoners who made it.cite webAuschwitz's sign of death and defiancehttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8420681.stmBBC NewsApril 23, 2015cite webB - the sculpturehttp://www.auschwitz.info/en/b-the-sculpture.htmlInternational Auschwitz CommitteeApril 23, 2015

In 1933 the first political prisoners were being rounded up for an indefinite period without charges. They were held in a number of places in Germany. The slogan was first used over the gate of a "wild camp" in the city ofOranienburg concentration campOranienburg, which was set up in an abandoned brewery in March 1933 (it was later rebuilt in 1936 asSachsenhausen (detention camp)Sachsenhausencitation neededFebruary 2013). It can also be seen at theDachau concentration camp,Gross-Rosen concentration camp, and theConcentration camp TheresienstadtTheresienstadtGhetto-Camp, as well as atFort BreendonkinBelgium. It has been claimed that the slogan was placed over entrance gates to Auschwitz III / Buna/Monowitz.Denis Avey with Rob BroombyThe Man who Broke into Auschwitz, Hodder and Stoughton, London, 2011 p.236Freddie Knoller with Robert LandawDesperate Journey: Vienna-Paris-Auschwitz, Metro, London, 2002, ISBN 978-184-358028-7 p.158The slogan appeared at theFlossenbrg concentration campFlossenbrgcamp on the left gate post at the camp entry. The original gate posts survive in another part of the camp, but the slogan sign no longer exists.KZ-Gedenkstaette FlossenbuergPrimo Levidescribes seeing the words illuminated over a doorway (as distinct from a gate) inMonowitz concentration campAuschwitz III/Buna Monowitz.Primo Levi, trans. Stuart Woolf,If This is a ManAbacus, London, 2004, p.28.
AtBuchenwald concentration campBuchenwald, "Jedem das Seine" (literally, "to each his own", but idiomatically "everyone gets what he deserves") was used.

In 1938 theAustrianpoliticalcabaretwriterJura Soyferand thecomposerHerbert Zipper, while prisoners atDachau Concentration Camp, wrote theDachaulied(The Dachau Song). They had spent weeks marching in and out of the camp's gate to dailyforced labour, and considered the motto "Arbeit macht frei" over the gate an insult. The song repeats the phrase cynically as a "lesson" taught by Dachau. (The first verse is translated in the article onJura Soyfer.)
InThe Kingdom of Auschwitz,Otto Friedrichwrote aboutRudolf Hss, regarding his decision to display the motto so prominently at the Auschwitz entrance:

list.listitem: He seems not to have intended it as a mockery, nor even to have intended it literally, as a false promise that those who worked to exhaustion would eventually be released, but rather as a kind of mystical declaration that self-sacrifice in the form of endless labour does in itself bring a kind of spiritual freedom.cite bookFriedrichOttoThe Kingdom of Auschwitz[[Harper Perennial]]August 1994978-0-06-097640-82–3

article.paragraph: Considering the role played by the Auschwitz prisons during the Holocaust as well as the individual prisoner's knowledge that once they entered the camp freedom was not likely to be obtained by any means other than death, the cruel comedy of the slogan becomes strikingly clear. The psychological impact it wrought on those who passed through the gates of each of the camps where it was seen was incredibly powerful.
article.heading: Thefts of "Arbeit Macht Frei" Signs
article.paragraph: Signs displaying the slogan at the interpretive centers which now occupy the former Nazi concentration camps have repeatedly been targeted by thieves. Motivation for the thefts was originally thought to be for financial gain, however when the individuals responsible for the theft were identified it was revealed that in at least one instance the thieves themselves were affiliated with theNeo-Nazimovement. What political goals that they hoped to achieve through stealing the signs is unclear.

The sign over Auschwitz was stolen in December 2009 and later recovered by authorities in three pieces. Anders Hgstrm, a Swedish neo-Nazi former leader, and two Poles were jailed as a result. The original sign is now in storage at theAuschwitz-Birkenau State Museumand a replica was put over the gate in its place.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12094855BBC NewsAuschwitz sign theft: Swedish man jailed30 December 2010

Five years later, the sign over the Dachau gate was stolen by unknown thieves. The November 2014 theft of the Dachau sign remains unsolved and the artifact has never been recovered.cite newshttp://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29878278BBCDachau infamous Nazi concentration camp gate stolen3 November 2014
